  • https://www.indeed.com/q-ukrainian-refugees-jobs.html?vjk=283e6b718ceff8d3

  • Rover (Animal Care)

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: EmployUkraine

item.title: Finding a Job
item.dc:creator: dbalin30
item.content:encoded:
Finding a Job

ðŸ§­ Step 1: Understand your options

The first step is to understand your options. There are a number of different ways to find a job in the USA, including:

  • Online job boards: There are many online job boards that list open positions in the USA. Some popular job boards include Indeed, Monster, and CareerBuilder.
  • Networking: Networking is a great way to find job leads. Talk to your friends, family, and former colleagues to see if they know of any open positions. You can also attend job fairs and networking events.
  • Reach out to employers directly: If you know of a specific company you would like to work for, you can reach out to them directly and inquire about job openings.
  • Use government resources: There are a number of government resources available to help Ukrainian refugees find jobs in the USA. These resources can provide you with job training, help you with your resume and cover letter, and connect you with potential employers.

ðŸ“ Step 2: Prepare your resume and cover letter

Once you have a good understanding of your options, it is time to start preparing your resume and cover letter. Your resume should highlight your skills and experience, and your cover letter should explain why you are interested in the job and why you would be a good fit.

âœ‰ï¸ Step 3: Start applying for jobs

Once you have your resume and cover letter ready, you can start applying for jobs. When applying for jobs, be sure to tailor your resume and cover letter to each specific position. You should also research the company you are applying to and mention why you are interested in working for them.

ðŸ’¬ Step 4: Prepare for interviews

Once you start getting interviews, it is important to be prepared. Practice answering common interview questions, and dress professionally. You should also arrive at your interview on time and be polite and respectful to the interviewer.

ðŸ¤ Step 5: Follow up after interviews

After your interview, be sure to send a thank-you note to the interviewer. You can also follow up with the interviewer a few days after the interview to see if they have any additional questions.

item.title: Work Permit (EAD)
item.dc:creator: dbalin30
item.content:encoded:
How to Get a Work Permit (EAD) in the US

What is a Work Permit (EAD)?

A work permit is a document that allows you to work legally in a foreign country. In the United States, work permits are issued by the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS).

â˜‘ï¸ Step 1: Understand your eligibility

The first step is to understand your eligibility for a work permit. There are a number of different factors that determine whether or not you are eligible, including your immigration status, your education level, and your skills and experience.

  • Immigration status: If you are a Ukrainian refugee who has been granted parole into the USA under the Uniting for Ukraine program, you are automatically eligible for work authorization.
  • Education level: If you have a high school diploma or equivalent, you are generally eligible for a work permit. However, if you have a college degree, you may be eligible for a more specialized work permit.
  • Skills and experience: If you have relevant skills and experience, you are more likely to be approved for a work permit.

ðŸ“‚ Step 2: Gather your documentation

Once you have determined that you are eligible for a work permit, you will need to gather the necessary documentation. This documentation will vary depending on your immigration status and other factors. However, some common documents that you may need to provide include:

  • A copy of your passport
  • A copy of your Form I-94, Arrival/Departure Record
  • A copy of your Form I-730, Refugee/Asylee Travel Document
  • A copy of your diploma or equivalent
  • Proof of your skills and experience

ðŸ“ Step 3: File the necessary paperwork

Once you have gathered your documentation, you will need to file the necessary paperwork with the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS). The specific paperwork you need to file will vary depending on your immigration status and other factors. However, you will generally need to file Form I-765, Application for Employment Authorization.

ðŸ’¸ Step 4: Pay the filing fee

There is a filing fee for Form I-765. The amount of the fee will vary depending on your immigration status. You can pay the filing fee online, by mail, or in person at a USCIS office.

ðŸ©º Step 5: Attend your biometrics appointment

Once you have filed your paperwork, you will be scheduled for a biometrics appointment. At your biometrics appointment, you will provide your fingerprints and a photograph.

ðŸŽ‰ Step 6: Wait for a decision

After you have completed all of the necessary steps, you will need to wait for a decision from USCIS. The processing time for work permit applications can vary depending on a number of factors. However, you should generally expect to wait several months for a decision.

item.title: Starting a Business
item.dc:creator: dbalin30
item.content:encoded:
How to Start Your Own Business in the US

  1. ðŸ’¼ Legal Status and Work Authorization: Ensure that you have a legal status in the US that allows you to work and start a business. Contact the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) or consult with an immigration attorney to understand the requirements and processes related to your situation.
  2. ðŸ‘¨â€ðŸ’¼ Business Structure: Choose a suitable legal structure for your business, such as a sole proprietorship, partnership, limited liability company (LLC), or corporation. Each structure has its own implications on liability, taxes, and governance. Research and consult with an attorney or business advisor to determine the best option for you.
  3. ðŸ–¨ï¸ Register Your Business: Register your business with the appropriate state and local authorities. The registration process may vary depending on your location. Below are links to resources that provide detailed information on business registration in different states:
    • For general information on business registration: SBA Business Registration Guide
  4. ðŸ’³ Obtain an Employer Identification Number (EIN): An EIN is a unique identifier for your business and is necessary for tax purposes and hiring employees. You can obtain an EIN from the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) by completing Form SS-4. Visit the following link for more information and to apply for an EIN: Apply for an EIN
  5. ðŸ—ƒï¸ Permits and Licenses: Determine if your business requires any specific permits or licenses to operate legally. The requirements vary depending on the type of business and location. Visit the following links for resources that provide information on licenses and permits based on business type:
    • SBA License and Permit Lookup Tool
  6. ðŸ¦ Comply with Tax Obligations: Understand and fulfill your tax obligations as a business owner. Familiarize yourself with federal, state, and local tax requirements. Consult with a tax professional or visit the following links for more information:
    • IRS Small Business and Self-Employed Tax Center

item.title: Documentation
item.dc:creator: dbalin30
item.content:encoded:
Full USA Documentation Checklist â¬‡ï¸

ðŸ›‚ Identification Documents:

  • Passport: Your valid Ukrainian passport serves as an important form of identification. It is recommended to keep your passport in a safe place and carry a photocopy for day-to-day identification needs.
  • Driver's License or State ID: Obtaining a driver's license or state identification (ID) card from Washington State's Department of Licensing is beneficial for identification purposes within the state.

ðŸ“‚ Immigration Documents:

  • Refugee Documentation: Your refugee identification card or official immigration documents, such as Form I-94 (Arrival/Departure Record), are crucial for proving your refugee status and lawful presence in the United States.
  • Employment Authorization Document (EAD): If you have obtained an EAD, also known as a work permit, it is essential to keep it up-to-date. This document allows you to work legally in the United States and may be required by employers when seeking employment.

ðŸ§¾Social Security Number (SSN):

  • Applying for an SSN: Applying for a Social Security Number is important for various purposes, including employment, accessing government benefits, and filing tax returns. To apply for an SSN, visit your local Social Security Administration (SSA) office and provide the required documents, such as your passport, immigration documents, and proof of employment eligibility.

ðŸ¡Housing Documents:

  • Lease Agreement or Rental Contract: If you are renting a home or apartment, keeping a copy of your lease agreement or rental contract is important for proof of residence and establishing your tenancy rights.
  • Utility Bills: Retaining copies of utility bills, such as electricity, water, or gas bills, can serve as additional proof of residence when needed.

ðŸŽ’ Education and Credentials:

  • Educational Certificates and Transcripts: Gather copies of your educational certificates, diplomas, and transcripts from Ukraine. These documents may be required for educational or professional purposes.
  • Professional Credentials and Licenses: If you hold any professional credentials or licenses from Ukraine, it may be beneficial to obtain an evaluation or translation of these documents to demonstrate your qualifications in the United States.

â˜Žï¸ Important Contacts:

  • Resettlement Agency: Keep contact information for the resettlement agency that assisted you during your refugee resettlement process. They can provide guidance and support regarding documentation and other settlement matters.
  • Legal Assistance: If you require legal advice or assistance, keep contact information for immigration attorneys or legal aid organizations that specialize in refugee and immigration matters.

item.title: Form I-94
item.dc:creator: dbalin30
item.content:encoded:
Form I-94

ðŸ“Form I-94, also known as the Arrival/Departure Record, is an important document for Ukrainian refugees. It serves as proof of your lawful admission to the United States and contains essential information regarding your immigration status and authorized period of stay.

ðŸŽ«Purpose of Form I-94:

Form I-94 is used to record the arrival and departure of non-immigrant individuals, including Ukrainian refugees, to the United States. It establishes your immigration status and authorized period of stay in the country. Form I-94 contains crucial information, including your admission number, class of admission, and the date until which you are authorized to stay in the United States.

ðŸ›‚Obtaining Form I-94:

As a Ukrainian refugee, you typically receive Form I-94 upon arrival in the United States. Here's how you can obtain it:

  • Port of Entry: When you first enter the United States, you will go through immigration and customs at a designated Port of Entry (airport, land border, or seaport). At the Port of Entry, a U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) officer will review your travel documents and process your entry into the country. They will provide you with Form I-94.

ðŸ–¨ï¸How to find your Form I-94 number (or print for other family members)

If you have lost your Form I-94, you can find your Form I-94 number online. You can do this by visiting the CBP website.

https://i94.cbp.dhs.gov/I94/#/home (MOST RECENT 1-94)

ðŸš¨Importance of Form I-94:

Form I-94 serves several essential purposes for Ukrainian refugees in Washington State:

  • Proof of Lawful Admission: It acts as proof of your lawful admission to the United States as a refugee.
  • Proof of Immigration Status: Form I-94 establishes your immigration status as a refugee and provides important information to government agencies, employers, educational institutions, and other entities when required.
  • Expiration Date: Pay close attention to the "Admit Until Date" on your Form I-94. It indicates the authorized period of stay in the United States. Ensure that you maintain your refugee status and take appropriate steps to extend or adjust your status if needed.

item.title: Social Security Number (SSN)
item.dc:creator: dbalin30
item.content:encoded:
Social Security Number (SSN)

ðŸŽŸï¸ What is a Social Security Number (SSN)?

A Social Security Number is a unique nine-digit identification number issued by the Social Security Administration (SSA) to U.S. citizens, permanent residents, and certain eligible noncitizens. It is used to track individuals' earnings and benefits in the United States.

ðŸ¤” Why Do You Need an SSN?

Having an SSN as a Ukrainian refugee in Washington State offers several benefits, including:

  • Employment: An SSN is essential for obtaining employment, as employers often require it for payroll and tax purposes.
  • Government Benefits: An SSN is necessary to access various government benefits and programs, such as Social Security retirement or disability benefits, Medicare, and unemployment benefits.
  • Financial Services: Many financial institutions, including banks and credit unions, require an SSN when opening accounts or applying for loans.
  • Tax Filing: An SSN is used to file income tax returns and claim tax credits and deductions.
  • Education: Some educational institutions may require an SSN for enrollment or financial aid purposes.
  • Identification: An SSN serves as an identification number for many official and financial transactions.

ðŸ“„ Steps for Applying for an SSN:

Ukrainian refugees in Washington State can apply for an SSN through the following methods:

  1. In the Social Security Administration (SSA): FORM: https://www.ssa.gov/forms/ss-5.pdf
    • Fill out an application for a Social Security Card (Form SS-5).
    • Gather the required documents, including your passport and Form I-94 (Arrival/Departure Record).
    • Visit the nearest SSA office in your area and submit the application along with the supporting documents.
    • The SSA will process your application, and you will receive your Social Security Card by mail in approximately two weeks.
  2. Via an application for Employment Authorization:
    • When filling out Form I-765 (Request for Employment Authorization), check the boxes requesting a new Social Security card and consenting to the transfer of your information to the SSA.
    • Submit the completed Form I-765 to U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) along with any required supporting documents.
    • USCIS will process your Employment Authorization Document (EAD) application and forward your request for an SSN to the SSA.
    • The SSA will mail your Social Security Card to the address provided on your application.

item.title: Healthcare
item.dc:creator: dbalin30
item.content:encoded:
Overview of HealthCare System in WAðŸ«€

ðŸ¥Healthcare Providers:

  • Hospitals: Washington State is home to numerous hospitals and medical centers that offer a wide range of services, including emergency care, surgeries, specialized treatments, and outpatient services. Some well-known hospitals in Washington State include University of Washington Medical Center (Seattle), Virginia Mason Medical Center (Seattle), and Overlake Medical Center (Bellevue) Research hospitals in your area to find those that meet your healthcare needs.
  • Primary Care Physicians: Primary care physicians are the first point of contact for general medical care, preventive services, and coordination of healthcare. It's important to find a primary care physician in your area who can provide routine check-ups, manage chronic conditions, and refer you to specialists if needed.
  • Specialists: Washington State has a diverse network of specialists in various fields, including cardiology, dermatology, orthopedics, and more. Depending on your healthcare needs, you may require the expertise of specialists for specific conditions or treatments. Your primary care physician can help you find and coordinate care with specialists.

ðŸ“‹Health Insurance:

  • Health Insurance Options: Health insurance is vital for accessing healthcare services in Washington State. There are different health insurance options available, including private insurance plans, employer-sponsored plans, and government programs. Popular health insurance companies in Washington State include [Name of Insurance Company 1], [Name of Insurance Company 2], and [Name of Insurance Company 3]. Research and compare insurance plans to find one that suits your needs and budget.
  • Washington Healthplanfinder: The Washington Health Benefit Exchange operates the Washington Healthplanfinder, an online marketplace where individuals and families can compare and enroll in health insurance plans. The Healthplanfinder provides information on available plans, subsidies, and eligibility criteria for various government programs like Medicaid and the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP).
  • If You Have Health Insurance: If you have health insurance, schedule an appointment with a doctor in your health plan. You can find a doctor in your health plan via your health planâ€™s website (Find a Provider/Find Care section) or by calling the member services phone number on your health insurance card. Call the doctorâ€™s office to schedule an appointment. If the dates the office offers you are too far in the future, pick the first available date and ask the office to put you on a waitlist â€“ that way, if someone cancels their appointment, yours will be moved up. If you need an interpreter at the appointment, request it when scheduling the appointment. The clinic will provide an over-the-phone interpreter â€“ all clinics are required to do so by law. If you have an HMO insurance plan, you need to obtain a referral from your Primary Care Physician (PCP) in order to see a specialist. Most Medicaid plans also require PCP referrals for procedures and specialist visits. See Health Insurance page for more information.
  • If You Do Not Have Health Insurance: If you do not have health insurance, you can visit a doctor at a free clinic or community clinic. Free clinics can be found via websites NAFCClinics.org, HRSA.gov, and NeedyMeds.org. To find a community clinic, google â€œcommunity clinic near me.â€ Community clinics charge for services on a sliding scale â€“ depending on household income. They also accept â€œstraightâ€ Medicaid â€“ that is, generic Medicaid insurance before you have chosen a particular plan. Some community clinics have urgent care clinics and dental services.

ðŸ©ºAccessing Medical Services:

  • Primary Care Visits: Establishing a relationship with a primary care physician is essential for routine check-ups, preventive care, and managing your overall health. Schedule regular visits with your primary care physician to address any health concerns and receive appropriate care.
  • Urgent Care Centers: Urgent care centers provide immediate medical attention for non-life-threatening conditions that require prompt attention but do not require an emergency room visit. These centers offer extended hours and can address issues such as minor injuries, illnesses, and common medical conditions.
  • Emergency Services: In case of a life-threatening situation or severe medical emergency, call 911 or go to the nearest emergency room. Emergency rooms are equipped to handle critical conditions and provide urgent medical care.
  • Pharmacies: Pharmacies are available throughout Washington State and play a crucial role in dispensing prescription medications and providing over-the-counter medications. Locate pharmacies in your area to fill prescriptions and access essential healthcare products.

ðŸ’ŠPrescription Medicine:

  • Obtaining Prescriptions: Many types of medication available over the counter in Ukraine require a prescription in the U.S. To obtain a prescription for the medication you need, visit a primary care provider or a specialist and have them write a U.S. prescription. If you do not have health insurance, you can get the prescription from a doctor at your local community clinic. If you have a Ukrainian or European prescription, you can ask a doctor to issue a prescription for the same medicine in the U.S. remotely using free telemedicine services for Ukrainians, such as [**https://khealth.com/ukraine.**].
  • Pharmacy Options: When filling a prescription, check in advance which pharmacies near you accept your health plan if you have insurance. For those without insurance, many prescription drugs can be bought at discounted rates with GoodRx coupons. Search for the medication you need on the Goodrx.com website, pick the pharmacy with the lowest price, print the coupon, and show it to the pharmacist.

â¤ï¸â€ðŸ©¹Mental Health and Psychological Help:

  • Coverage for Mental Health Services: Any health insurance, including Medicaid, provides coverage for mental health services. If you are feeling suicidal or in danger of hurting yourself or others, go to the emergency room, a community health clinic, or an urgent care clinic to receive immediate psychiatric help and medication.
  • Therapy Resources: There are free or low-cost therapy resources available in Ukrainian or Russian for Ukrainians affected by war: Ð Ð¾Ð·ÐºÐ°Ð¶Ð¸ ÐœÐµÐ½Ñ– ÐŸiÐ´Ñ‚Ñ€Ð¸Ð¼ÐºÐ°.Online ÐŸÑÐ¸Ñ…Ð¾Ð»Ð¾Ð³Ñ–Ñ‡Ð½Ð¸Ð¹ ÑÑƒÐ¿Ñ€Ð¾Ð²Ñ–Ð´ Ð£ÐºÑ€Ð°Ñ—Ð½Ð¸ Ð Ð°Ð·Ð¾Ð¼ TreatField Itâ€™s Complicated Therapy Route PPSC

ðŸª™Managing Healthcare Costs:

  • Emergency Medicaid Coverage: If you are low-income and do not have health insurance, you may qualify for emergency Medicaid coverage. Emergency Medicaid covers emergency room visits and unforeseen hospitalizations. You can apply for retroactive coverage and submit your bill to Medicaid after your insurance application is approved.
  • Installment Payments: If you cannot afford to pay a medical bill, contact the hospital billing department using the number provided on the bill. Explain your situation and ask if they can allow you to pay the bill in monthly installments. Inquire about any discount programs for people without health insurance.
  • Payment through Charities: Hospitals may work with charities that help people without health insurance pay their bills. Inquire with the hospital billing department or search for local charities that offer assistance with medical bills.
  • Addressing Medical Debt: It is important not to ignore medical bills or let them go to collections, as they can negatively impact your credit score. This can make it challenging to secure housing, obtain loans or credit cards, or make large purchases in the future.

item.title: Job Market in WA
item.dc:creator: dbalin30
item.content:encoded:
Job Market in WA

ðŸ“ˆ The job market in Washington State is strong, with a low unemployment rate and a variety of industries to choose from. This makes it a great place for Ukrainian refugees to find employment.

Some of the industries with the most job openings in Washington State include:

  • ðŸ§‘â€ðŸ’» Technology: Washington State is home to a number of technology companies, including Microsoft, Amazon, and Google. These companies are constantly hiring for a variety of positions, including software engineers, data scientists, and customer service representatives. Technology companies in Washington State
  • ðŸ’‰ Healthcare: Washington State has a large and growing healthcare industry. There are many job openings for nurses, doctors, and other healthcare professionals. Healthcare companies in Washington State
  • âœˆï¸ Manufacturing: Washington State is home to a number of manufacturing companies, including Boeing, Weyerhaeuser, and Starbucks. These companies are constantly hiring for a variety of positions, including machinists, welders, and electricians.
  • ðŸŒ²Tourism: Washington State is a popular tourist destination, with a number of national parks, forests, and beaches. There are many job openings for tour guides, hotel staff, and restaurant workers.

ðŸ’¼ How to find a job in Washington State:

There are a number of ways to find a job in Washington State. Here are a few tips:

  • Use online job boards: There are a number of online job boards that list openings in Washington State. Some popular job boards include Indeed, Monster, and CareerBuilder.
  • Contact staffing agencies: Staffing agencies can help you find temporary or contract work. They can also help you find permanent employment.
  • Network with people in your field: Talk to your friends, family, and former colleagues to see if they know of any job openings. You can also attend industry events and meetups to meet new people and learn about job opportunities.
  • Contact refugee resettlement agencies: Refugee resettlement agencies can help you find job training and placement services.

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: dbalin30
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:

Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)

...or something like this:

The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.

As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: dbalin30
item.content:encoded:
Who we are

Suggested text: Our website address is: http://ukrainetest.local.

Comments

Suggested text: When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitor’s IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection.

An anonymized string created from your email address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it. The Gravatar service privacy policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment.

Media

Suggested text: If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website.

Cookies

Suggested text: If you leave a comment on our site you may opt-in to saving your name, email address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year.

If you visit our login page, we will set a temporary cookie to determine if your browser accepts cookies. This cookie contains no personal data and is discarded when you close your browser.

When you log in, we will also set up several cookies to save your login information and your screen display choices. Login cookies last for two days, and screen options cookies last for a year. If you select "Remember Me", your login will persist for two weeks. If you log out of your account, the login cookies will be removed.

If you edit or publish an article, an additional cookie will be saved in your browser. This cookie includes no personal data and simply indicates the post ID of the article you just edited. It expires after 1 day.

Embedded content from other websites

Suggested text: Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website.

These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website.

Who we share your data with

Suggested text: If you request a password reset, your IP address will be included in the reset email.

How long we retain your data

Suggested text: If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognize and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue.

For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information.

What rights you have over your data

Suggested text: If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes.

Where your data is sent

Suggested text: Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

item.title: Housing
item.dc:creator: dbalin30
item.content:encoded: default housing content

item.title: Renting an Apartment/House
item.dc:creator: dbalin30
item.content:encoded:
Renting an Apartment or House

ðŸ”— Helpful Links:

  1. Zillow: A popular online platform for rental listings and real estate information.
  2. Apartments.com: Provides a wide range of apartment listings across the USA.
  3. Rent.com: Offers a comprehensive database of rental properties and useful resources.
  4. Craigslist: A classified advertisements website where you can find local rental listings.

ðŸ¡ Steps:

Renting an apartment or house is a common choice for Ukrainian refugees settling in the USA. Here are some important considerations and steps to follow:

  1. Determine Your Budget:
    • Assess your financial situation and determine how much you can afford to spend on rent each month.
    • Take into account other expenses such as utilities, insurance, and maintenance costs.
  2. Research Rental Market:
    • Explore popular rental websites and online classifieds to get an idea of the rental prices in your desired area.
    • Check out local newspapers or community bulletin boards for potential rental listings.
    • Consider working with a real estate agent who specializes in rentals.
  3. Define Your Preferences:
    • Make a list of your housing preferences, including the number of bedrooms, location, amenities, and proximity to schools or workplaces.
    • Prioritize your preferences to help narrow down your options.
  4. Contact Landlords or Property Managers:
    • Reach out to landlords or property management companies to inquire about available rentals.
    • Prepare a list of questions regarding lease terms, security deposit, utilities, and any specific requirements.
  5. Schedule Property Viewings:
    • Arrange appointments to visit the properties that match your criteria.
    • Take note of the condition of the property, any maintenance issues, and whether it meets your needs.
  6. Review Lease Agreement:
    • Carefully read and understand the lease agreement before signing.
    • Pay attention to terms regarding rent amount, lease duration, security deposit, pet policies, and maintenance responsibilities.
  7. Arrange for Tenant Screening:
    • Landlords may require a background check or credit report as part of the application process.
    • Gather necessary documents such as identification, proof of employment or income, and references.
  8. Move-in Preparations:
    • Coordinate with the landlord or property manager to schedule the move-in date and obtain keys.
    • Arrange for utilities and services to be transferred or set up in your name, including electricity, water, and internet.

item.title: Refugee Housing
item.dc:creator: dbalin30
item.content:encoded:
Refugee Housing

ðŸ§­Resources:

ICanHelp.host

Host4Ukraine.com

SolSacramento.com

USA.Canada.Help.Shelter

HopeStay.org

Ukraina.Space

There are a number of different ways to find temporary housing accommodation in the US as a Ukrainian refugee. Here are a few options:

  • Government-sponsored programs: The US government and a number of non-profit organizations offer programs that provide temporary housing to Ukrainian refugees. These programs can be a great option if you are not able to find other housing options.
  • Private landlords: There are also a number of private landlords who offer temporary housing to Ukrainian refugees. You can find these landlords by searching online or by contacting local refugee resettlement agencies.
  • Housing charities: There are also a number of housing charities that provide temporary housing to Ukrainian refugees. These charities may be able to offer you housing at a reduced cost or even free of charge.

item.title: WA Housing Market 2023
item.dc:creator: dbalin30
item.content:encoded:
WA Housing Market 2023 (By Major City)

ðŸ’¸The housing market in Washington State is notoriously expensive, but there are still some affordable options available for Ukrainian refugees. Here is a breakdown of the cost of rent in different parts of the state:

ðŸ¦There are a number of government programs that can help Ukrainian refugees with housing costs. These programs include:

  • The Refugee Cash Assistance (RCA) program: This program provides refugees with a monthly cash payment to help cover basic living expenses, including rent.
  • The Refugee Medical Assistance (RMA) program: This program provides refugees with free or low-cost healthcare coverage.
  • The Section 8 Housing Choice Voucher program: This program helps refugees pay rent for privately-owned apartments.

item.title: VISA
item.dc:creator: dbalin30
item.content:encoded:
On April 21, 2022, President Biden announced Uniting for Ukraine, a new streamlined process to provide Ukrainian citizens who have fled Russiaâ€™s unprovoked war of aggression opportunities to come to the United States. This represents a key step toward fulfilling the Presidentâ€™s commitment to welcome Ukrainians fleeing Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine.  Visit this link for information on how to apply.

21 ÐºÐ²Ñ–Ñ‚Ð½Ñ 2022 Ñ€Ð¾ÐºÑƒ ÐŸÑ€ÐµÐ·Ð¸Ð´ÐµÐ½Ñ‚ Ð‘Ð°Ð¹Ð´ÐµÐ½ Ð¾Ð³Ð¾Ð»Ð¾ÑÐ¸Ð² Ñ–Ð½Ñ–Ñ†Ñ–Ð°Ñ‚Ð¸Ð²Ñƒ Â«ÐžÐ±â€™Ñ”Ð´Ð½ÑƒÑ”Ð¼Ð¾ÑÑŒ Ð·Ð°Ñ€Ð°Ð´Ð¸ Ð£ÐºÑ€Ð°Ñ—Ð½Ð¸Â», Ð½Ð¾Ð²Ð¸Ð¹ ÑÐ¿Ñ€Ð¾Ñ‰ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ð¹ Ð¿Ñ€Ð¾Ñ†ÐµÑ Ð½Ð°Ð´Ð°Ð½Ð½Ñ ÑƒÐºÑ€Ð°Ñ—Ð½Ñ†ÑÐ¼, Ñ‰Ð¾ Ñ‚Ñ–ÐºÐ°ÑŽÑ‚ÑŒ Ð²Ñ–Ð´ Ð½ÐµÑÐ¿Ñ€Ð¾Ð²Ð¾ÐºÐ¾Ð²Ð°Ð½Ð¾Ñ— Ð·Ð°Ð³Ð°Ñ€Ð±Ð½Ð¸Ñ†ÑŒÐºÐ¾Ñ— Ð²Ñ–Ð¹Ð½Ð¸ Ñ€Ð¾Ð·Ð¿Ð¾Ñ‡Ð°Ñ‚Ð¾Ñ— Ð Ð¾ÑÑ–Ñ”ÑŽ, Ð¼Ð¾Ð¶Ð»Ð¸Ð²Ð¾ÑÑ‚ÐµÐ¹ Ð¿Ñ€Ð¸Ñ—Ñ…Ð°Ñ‚Ð¸ Ð´Ð¾ Ð¡Ð¿Ð¾Ð»ÑƒÑ‡ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ñ… Ð¨Ñ‚Ð°Ñ‚Ñ–Ð². Ð¦Ðµ Ð³Ð¾Ð»Ð¾Ð²Ð½Ð¸Ð¹ ÐºÑ€Ð¾Ðº Ð½Ð° ÑˆÐ»ÑÑ…Ñƒ Ð²Ð¸ÐºÐ¾Ð½Ð°Ð½Ð½Ñ Ð·Ð¾Ð±Ð¾Ð²â€™ÑÐ·Ð°Ð½Ð½Ñ ÐŸÑ€ÐµÐ·Ð¸Ð´ÐµÐ½Ñ‚Ð° Ð¿Ñ€Ð¸Ð¹Ð¼Ð°Ñ‚Ð¸ ÑƒÐºÑ€Ð°Ñ—Ð½Ñ†Ñ–Ð² Ñ‰Ð¾ Ð±Ñ–Ð¶Ð°Ñ‚ÑŒ Ð²Ñ–Ð´ Ð½Ð°Ð¿Ð°Ð´Ñƒ Ð Ð¾ÑÑ–Ñ— Ð½Ð° Ð£ÐºÑ€Ð°Ñ—Ð½Ñƒ. ÐŸÐµÑ€ÐµÐ¹Ð´Ñ–Ñ‚ÑŒ Ð·Ð° Ð¿Ð¾ÑÐ¸Ð»Ð°Ð½Ð½ÑÐ¼ Uniting for Ukraine | Homeland Security (dhs.gov) Ð´Ð»Ñ Ñ–Ð½Ñ„Ð¾Ñ€Ð¼Ð°Ñ†Ñ–Ñ— ÑÑ‚Ð¾ÑÐ¾Ð²Ð½Ð¾ Ð¿Ñ€Ð¾Ñ†ÐµÑÑƒ Ð¿Ð¾Ð´Ð°Ð½Ð½Ñ Ð´Ð¾ÐºÑƒÐ¼ÐµÐ½Ñ‚Ñ–Ð².

If you are seeking information about immediate humanitarian assistance in Italy:

  • Almost all refugee cases in countries abroad are processed by local authorities, in this case the government of Italy.
  • Ukrainians should not contact the authorities of the United States or attempt to apply for visas in order to travel to the United States as refugeesâ€“such travel is not possible.  They should contact the authorities of Italy.  Contact information is below.
  • The Commune of Rome has implemented a â€œUkraine Emergencyâ€ Task Force for those with questions about options and resources available for Ukrainians in Italy:  tel: 800 93 88 73.  Email: emergenza.ucraina@comune.roma.it.  The Ukrainian Consulate in Milan is also working with the Commune and the Prefecture office to coordinate the arrival of refugees:  Milanoconsolato1@gmail.com.
  • Additional information is available from the United Nations High Commission for Refugees (UNHCR): https://www.unhcr.org/en-us/, including information about non-governmental organizations that may be able to provide additional assistance.

AMERICAN CITIZENS SERVICES

  • U.S. citizens wishing to move from Ukraine to other European countries can find important information on the State Departmentâ€™s Ukraine crisis page:  https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/ea/information-for-us-citizens-in-Ukraine.html.  That page also has helpful resources for U.S. citizens in Ukraine.
  • For information on applying for refugee, asylum or temporary protective status in Italy, please contact Italian authorities directly: The Commune of Rome has implemented a â€œUkraine Emergencyâ€ Task Force for those with questions about options and resources available for Ukrainians in Italy:  tel: 800 93 88 73.  Email: emergenza.ucraina@comune.roma.it.  The Ukrainian Consulate in Milan is also working with the Commune and the Prefecture office to coordinate the arrival of refugees:  Milanoconsolato1@gmail.com.  You can also find information via United Nations High Commission for Refugees (UNHCR) at https://www.unhcr.org/en-us/.
  • For information on refugee or asylum status in the United States, please visit: https://www.uscis.gov/humanitarian/refugees-and-asylum/usrap.  You can also find information via the United Nations High Commission for Refugees (UNHCR) at https://www.unhcr.org/en-us/.

VISA SERVICESâ€¯IN ITALY

IMMIGRANT VISAS

If you are aâ€¯U.S. citizen or Lawful Permanent Resident with a Ukrainian relativeâ€¯who seeks to travel to the United States on an immigrant visa:

  • If you have a Form I-130 petition approved by USCIS pending processing at the National Visa Center (NVC) and want to transfer it to another Embassy, the designated processing post for Ukrainian Immigrant Visas is U.S. Consulate General Frankfurt, Germany: https://de.usembassy.gov/ukrainians-in-germany/. You may request an appointment expedite and transfer from the National Visa Center:  https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/us-visas/immigrate/national-visa-center/nvc-contact-information.html
  • If you have not yet filed a petition but wish to do so, you may contact U.S. Consulate General in Naples to inquire about filing the I-130 petition in Italy.  This applies only to U.S. citizens filing petitions for their spouses, unmarried children under 21, and/or parents. Both the petitioner and the applicant must be present in Italy. The U.S. Consulate General in Naples processes all immigrant visas in Italy.
  • If you have an immigrant visa case that has already been transferred from NVC to Kyiv for the appointment and processing and you would like it to be processed in Naples, please send an email request with your case number (KEV+10 digits) to U.S. Consulate General in Naples: IVNaples@state.gov.
  • If you are already in Italy and have a Form I-130 petition approved by USCIS pending processing at the National Visa Center and want to transfer it to the U.S. Consulate General in Naples, you may request an expedited appointment and transfer from the National Visa Center:â€¯https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/us-visas/immigrate/national-visa-center/nvc-contact-information.html.
  • Diversity Visa (DV) applicants should follow the same guidance as regular immigrant visa cases and will have their unscheduled cases assigned to Frankfurt.  Please check https://dvprogram.state.gov/ for their caseâ€™s rank-order and interview status.  To request DV case transfer from the U.S. Consulate General in Frankfurt to the U.S. Consulate General in Naples, please request reassignment via KCCDV@state.gov.
  • If you have a question about an immigrant visa case that is already in process at the U.S. Consulate General in Naples, please email IVNaples@state.gov.

If you are a U.S. citizen with a Ukrainian fiancÃ©e/fiancÃ© seeking to travel to the United States on a K1 visa:

  • If you have already filed a petition with U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) that has not yet been approved, U.S. Embassies and consulates cannot accept K visa petitions (Form I-129F) for local filing abroad. USCIS must first approve the Form I-129F petition before a K-1 visa can be processed. However, you can request an expedite for USCIS processing at https://www.uscis.gov/forms/filing-guidance/how-to-make-an-expedite-request

NONIMMIGRANT VISAS

  • Before applying for a nonimmigrant visa, consider carefully whether you are qualified for the visa you intend to apply for. Please note that nonimmigrant visas are for temporary stays in the United States and are not for refugees. There are no nonimmigrant visas available for refugees. If you apply for a nonimmigrant visa but do not have credible plans to depart the United States after a temporary stay, your application will be refused.
  • There are no â€œwalk-upâ€ appointments available at U.S. Embassy Rome or at U.S. Consulates General in Milan, Florence, or Naples. You must have an appointment in advance in order to interview for a visa.
  • If you are not qualified for a nonimmigrant visa, you may wish to refer to the humanitarian assistance information above.
  • If you are a Ukrainian who wants to travel to the United States or a U.S. citizen who has friends, business associates, or NON-IMMEDIATE family who want to travel to the United States on a nonimmigrant visa you should go to https://ais.usvisa-info.com/and schedule your appointment.
  • Demand is extremely high, availability is low, and wait times and processing times are likely to be very lengthy. You may wish to refer to the humanitarian relief information above.
  • If you already have an appointment at U.S. Embassy Rome or at U.S. Consulates General in Milan, Florence or Naples but wish to expedite it, you may request an emergency appointment in your account on https://ais.usvisa-info.com/
  • Nonimmigrant visa applications started in Ukraine cannot be transferred to Italy. A new application fee is required. To apply for a nonimmigrant visa at the U.S. Embassy Rome or at the U.S. Consulates in Milan, Florence, or Naples, please follow the application process at https://ais.usvisa-info.com.
  • If you do not have all your documents available, for example a passport, you may apply without these documents. A consular officer will inform you of any required next steps as part of the visa decision.

item.title: Public Transportation Options
item.dc:creator: dbalin30
item.content:encoded:
Public Transportation Options in WA ðŸš„

FULL RESOURCE:

https://wa.gov/how-to-guides/use-public-transportation

ðŸ’³ Orca Card (for Buses):

The ORCA card is an easy way to pay your fare without having to carry cash. Use your ORCA card on Community Transit, Everett Transit, King County Metro, Kitsap Transit, Pierce Transit, Sound Transit, and Washington State Ferries, as well as on Monorail and Seattle Streetcar. You can load funds online or in person at ticket vending machines and the ORCA customer service office.

Get a card

The following are some of the types of public transportation available in Washington State:

  • ðŸšBuses: There are many bus lines that operate throughout the state. These buses can take you to major cities, small towns, and even rural areas. Buses in Washington State
    • King County Trip Planner:
      • Trip Planner
  • ðŸš†Trains: There are two major train lines in Washington State: Amtrak and Sound Transit. Amtrak provides long-distance service between Seattle and other major cities in the United States. Sound Transit operates a regional train system that serves the Puget Sound region.
    • Train schedules
    • Rail Lines of Washington
  • ðŸ›¤ï¸Light Rail: There is one light rail system in Washington State: Sound Transit Light Rail. This system operates in the Puget Sound region and connects Seattle, Tacoma, and other cities.
    • How to ride
    • Trip planner
  • â›´ï¸Ferries: There are many ferry routes that operate in Washington State. These ferries can take you to islands in the Puget Sound, the San Juan Islands, and even Alaska.
    • A guide for first time riders
    • Ferry schedules
    • Buy a ticket

How to Use Public Transportation

To use public transportation in Washington State, you will need to purchase a fare. You can purchase fares online, at ticket vending machines, or from the driver of the bus or train.

Once you have purchased a fare, you will need to validate it before you board the bus or train. You can validate your fare by inserting it into a farebox or by scanning it with a smartphone app.

https://www.soundtransit.org/ride-with-us/how-to-pay/fares

ðŸ“ƒ Resources

  • Washington State Department of Transportation: https://www.wsdot.wa.gov/
  • Sound Transit: https://www.soundtransit.org/
  • Amtrak: https://www.amtrak.com/

item.title: Renting/Buying a Car
item.dc:creator: dbalin30
item.content:encoded:
Renting or Buying a Car in WA

ðŸš— Renting a Car:

  • Rental Agencies: Washington State has several car rental agencies, both international and local. Some well-known rental companies include Enterprise , Hertz, and Alamo. Research and compare rental rates, terms, and conditions to find the best option for your needs.
  • Rental Requirements: To rent a car, you will typically need a valid driver's license, a major credit card, and proof of insurance. The rental agency may also have age restrictions or additional requirements, so it's important to review their specific policies.
  • Rental Insurance: When renting a car, the rental agency usually provides basic insurance coverage. However, it's recommended to consider additional insurance options such as Collision Damage Waiver (CDW) or Supplemental Liability Insurance (SLI) for added protection in case of accidents or damages. Check with the rental agency about available insurance options and coverage details.

ðŸ’µ Buying a Car:

  • New vs. Used Cars: Decide whether you want to buy a new or used car. New cars offer the latest features and warranties, while used cars are typically more affordable. Consider your budget, preferences, and long-term needs. Research reputable car dealerships in Washington State that offer the type of car you're interested in.
  • Car Dealerships: Visit car dealerships in person or explore their websites to view available inventory, compare prices, and read customer reviews. Interact with sales representatives to gather information about the car's history, maintenance records, and warranty coverage. Take the opportunity to test-drive the car before making a decision.
  • Vehicle History Reports: When buying a used car, obtaining a vehicle history report is highly recommended. Services like Carfax or AutoCheck provide information about the vehicle's accident history, title status, previous owners, and maintenance records. This report can help you make an informed decision about the condition and reliability of the car.
  • Financing Options: If you require financial assistance to purchase a car, explore financing options such as bank loans or dealership financing. Compare interest rates, monthly payment plans, and loan terms. Ensure you understand the terms and conditions, including any potential penalties for early repayment or missed payments.

ðŸ“„ Vehicle Registration:

  • Registering Your Vehicle: After purchasing a car in Washington State, you must register it with the Washington State Department of Licensing (DOL) within 30 days. You can visit a local DOL office or complete the registration process online through the DOL's website.
  • Required Documents: Prepare the necessary documents for vehicle registration, including the vehicle title, bill of sale, proof of insurance, and identification (such as your driver's license). Additionally, if the car was purchased from a private seller, a signed odometer disclosure statement may be required.
  • Registration Fees: Be aware of the registration fees and taxes associated with vehicle registration in Washington State. These fees may vary depending on factors such as the vehicle's value and weight. You can find detailed information about registration fees on the DOL's website or by contacting a local DOL office.

ðŸ”§ Car Insurance:

  • Auto Insurance Requirements: In Washington State, auto insurance is mandatory. You must have liability insurance coverage that meets the state's minimum requirements. This coverage includes bodily injury liability and propertydamage liability. The minimum liability coverage limits are $25,000 per person for bodily injury, $50,000 per accident for bodily injury, and $10,000 per accident for property damage.
  • Finding an Insurance Provider: Research different insurance providers in Washington State and obtain quotes from multiple companies to compare coverage options and premiums. Consider factors such as customer reviews, financial stability of the insurance company, and the level of customer service provided.
  • Additional Insurance Coverage: While liability insurance is the minimum requirement, it's worth considering additional coverage options for comprehensive and collision insurance. Comprehensive insurance covers damages to your vehicle caused by events other than collisions, such as theft, vandalism, or natural disasters. Collision insurance covers damages to your vehicle resulting from a collision with another vehicle or object. Assess your needs and budget to determine if additional coverage is necessary.
  • Proof of Insurance: Always carry proof of insurance in your vehicle. The insurance company will provide you with an insurance card that includes details of your coverage. You may be required to present this card in case of accidents, traffic stops, or vehicle inspections.

item.title: Airports
item.dc:creator: dbalin30
item.content:encoded:
Airports (WA)âœˆï¸

Washington State has four major airports: Seattle-Tacoma International Airport (SEA), Spokane International Airport (GEG), Paine Field Airport (PAE), and Bellingham International Airport (BLI). These airports serve millions of passengers each year and offer a variety of transportation options.

Seattle-Tacoma International Airport (SEA)

Learn More

SEA is the largest airport in Washington State and the 14th busiest airport in the United States. It is located in SeaTac, Washington, just south of Seattle. SEA offers flights to over 100 destinations in the United States, Canada, Mexico, and internationally.

Spokane International Airport (GEG)

Learn More

GEG is the second largest airport in Washington State and the 71st busiest airport in the United States. It is located in Spokane, Washington, in the eastern part of the state. GEG offers flights to over 30 destinations in the United States, Canada, and Mexico.

Paine Field Airport (PAE)

Learn More

PAE is a smaller airport located in Everett, Washington, north of Seattle. PAE offers flights to over 20 destinations in the United States.

Transportation Options

All three of the major airports in Washington State offer a variety of transportation options, including:

  • Ground transportation: There are many bus and taxi companies that serve the airports. You can also rent a car from one of the many car rental agencies located at the airports.
  • Public transportation: The Sound Transit Light Rail system serves SEA and GEG. There are also bus lines that serve all three airports.
  • Shared ride: There are several shared ride companies that operate in Washington State. These companies offer rides to and from the airports at a lower cost than taxis or rental cars.

item.title: Driving License
item.dc:creator: dbalin30
item.content:encoded:
Driving License in WA ðŸ’³

ðŸ‘Eligibility:

To be eligible for a driving license in Washington State as a Ukrainian refugee, you must meet the following requirements:

  • Be at least 16 years old to apply for an instruction permit, or 18 years old for a regular driver's license.
  • Provide proof of your legal presence in the United States as a Ukrainian refugee.
  • Pass the required knowledge and driving tests.

ðŸ“„Required Documents:

Before applying for a driving license, gather the following documents:

  • Proof of Identity: Provide identification documents such as your valid Ukrainian passport, refugee travel document, or other acceptable forms of identification.
  • Proof of Legal Presence: Present documents that verify your legal presence in the United States as a Ukrainian refugee. This may include your refugee travel document, I-94 arrival/departure record, Employment Authorization Document (EAD), or other immigration documents.
  • Social Security Number: If you have been assigned a Social Security Number (SSN), provide the SSN card or the official documentation issued by the Social Security Administration.
  • Proof of Washington State Residency: Show proof of your Washington State residency, such as utility bills, rental agreement, or bank statements with your name and address.
  • Proof of Name Change (if applicable): If your name has changed, provide legal documents such as marriage certificates, divorce decrees, or court orders indicating the name change.

ðŸªœSteps to Obtain a Driving License:

  1. Study the Washington Driver Guide: Obtain a copy of the Washington State Driver Guide and thoroughly study its contents. This guide provides important information about traffic laws, road signs, and safe driving practices.
  2. Apply for an Instruction Permit: Visit a local Department of Licensing (DOL) office and submit the required documents mentioned above. Pass a vision test and a written knowledge test based on the information in the Driver Guide. Pay the appropriate fees. Upon successful completion, you will receive an instruction permit.
  3. Practice Driving: With your instruction permit, you are allowed to practice driving under the supervision of a licensed adult who is at least 21 years old and has a valid driver's license.
  4. Schedule and Pass the Driving Test: Once you feel comfortable with your driving skills, schedule a driving test at a DOL licensing office. During the test, you will be assessed on your ability to demonstrate safe driving maneuvers and follow traffic laws. If you pass the driving test, you will be issued a Washington State driver's license.

ðŸ”‘Additional Information:

  • Fees: Be prepared to pay the required fees for each step of the process. Fees may vary, so check the DOL website or contact a local DOL office for the most up-to-date information.
  • Knowledge and Driving Tests: The knowledge test consists of multiple-choice questions about traffic laws, road signs, and safe driving practices. The driving test assesses your ability to operate a motor vehicle safely. Familiarize yourself with the specific requirements and test formats to increase your chances of success.
  • Driver Training Programs: Consider enrolling in a driver training program or taking driving lessons to gain confidence and improve your driving skills. These programs can help you become a safer and more knowledgeable driver.
  • License Renewal: Washington State driver's licenses are typically valid for six years. Stay updated on the renewal process and

item.title: Traffic Laws and Road Safety
item.dc:creator: dbalin30
item.content:encoded:
Traffic Laws and Safety

ðŸš¦Traffic Laws:

  • Seat Belt Laws: In Washington State, seat belt usage is strictly enforced. All occupants in a vehicle must wear seat belts, including passengers in the back seat. It is the responsibility of the driver to ensure that all passengers, including children, are properly restrained. This is a significant difference from some countries where seat belt laws may be less strictly enforced.
  • Distracted Driving: Washington State has strict laws against distracted driving, including the use of handheld electronic devices while driving. It is illegal to text, talk on the phone without a hands-free device, or engage in any other activity that diverts attention from the road. This may differ from enforcement levels in Ukraine, so it's crucial to understand and comply with these laws in Washington State.
  • Right-of-Way: Understanding and yielding the right-of-way is important in Washington State. Follow the rules at intersections, crosswalks, and when merging or changing lanes. Yield to pedestrians, bicyclists, and other drivers as required by traffic signs and signals. This emphasis on right-of-way may be stricter than what you're accustomed to in Ukraine.
  • Driving Under the Influence (DUI): Driving with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08% or higher is considered a DUI offense in Washington State. Penalties for DUI convictions can be severe and may include fines, license suspension, and even imprisonment. It's crucial to recognize that the legal BAC limit in Washington State is lower than in some other countries.
  • Traffic Signals and Signs: Observe and obey traffic signals, signs, and road markings. This includes understanding the meaning of different signs, such as stop signs, yield signs, and various traffic signals (green, yellow, and red lights). Familiarize yourself with these specific signs and signals as they may differ from what you're used to in Ukraine.

ðŸ›£ï¸Road Safety Practices:

  • Defensive Driving: Practicing defensive driving techniques is crucial in Washington State. This means anticipating and reacting to potential hazards, maintaining a safe following distance, and staying alert to your surroundings. Defensive driving helps mitigate risks and promotes overall road safety.
  • Adverse Weather Conditions: Be prepared for adverse weather conditions, such as heavy rain, fog, snow, and icy roads, which are common in Washington State. Adjust your driving behavior, reduce speed, and increase following distance during inclement weather. This is particularly important given the diverse weather patterns and potential challenges in navigating the roads.
  • Pedestrian and Bicyclist Safety: In Washington State, there is a strong emphasis on pedestrian and bicyclist safety. It is important to yield to pedestrians at crosswalks, share the road with bicyclists, and maintain a safe distance when passing cyclists. This emphasis on sharing the road may differ from some other countries, and it's essential to be attentive and respectful to vulnerable road users.
  • School Zones: Special attention must be paid to school zones in Washington State. Observe reduced speed limits during designated hours, watch for children crossing the road, and exercise caution around school buses. This level of vigilance is an important aspect of ensuring the safety of schoolchildren.
  • Emergency Vehicles: When emergency vehicles with lights and sirens approach, it's crucial to pull over to the right side of the road and come to a stop. Allow emergency vehicles to pass safely. This ensures the prompt response and safety of those in need of emergency assistance.

ðŸš¨Reporting Incidents and Emergencies:

  • Accidents: If you're involved in a vehicle collision in Washington State, it's important to stop at the scene and exchange information with the other party involved. If necessary, contact law enforcement to report the accident. It's essential to have valid insurance and carry proof of insurance in your vehicle, as required by law.
  • Emergencies: In case of emergencies or the need for roadside assistance, dial 911 for immediate assistance in Washington State. Be prepared to provide your location, a description of the situation, and any relevant details to the emergency dispatcher.

item.title: Uniting for Ukraine (U4U)
item.dc:creator: dbalin30
item.content:encoded:
Uniting for Ukraine (U4U)

Overview of the Uniting for Ukraine Program:

The Uniting for Ukraine Program offers a pathway for Ukrainian nationals affected by Russia's aggression to seek lawful entry into the United States. This program is designed to provide humanitarian relief and support to those who have been displaced due to the conflict. By granting humanitarian parole, eligible individuals can legally stay in the U.S. for a specified period, during which they are authorized to work, and their children can attend school.

  • What is humanitarian parole?
    • A temporary status granted to individuals who are otherwise inadmissible to the United States due to an emergency or other urgent humanitarian situation. It allows them to enter and stay in the U.S. for a temporary period of time.

Eligibility for the Uniting for Ukraine Program:

To be eligible for the Uniting for Ukraine Program, individuals must meet the following criteria:

  1. Ukrainian Citizenship: Applicants must be citizens of Ukraine and possess a valid Ukrainian passport. Children can be included in a parent's passport.
  2. Displacement due to the Conflict: Individuals must have resided in Ukraine prior to the conflict and have been displaced as a result of the ongoing conflict.
  3. Supporter's Application: A supporter, who can be a U.S. citizen, green card holder, asylee, TPS holder, person on humanitarian parole, or person on a long-term visa, must file a specific application on behalf of the Ukrainian beneficiary. This application is carefully reviewed and vetted by the immigration service.
  4. Biographic Security Checks: Applicants must pass biographic security checks conducted by the U.S. government.

Supporter Informationâ€¦

  • See next page (U4U Supporter) â†’

item.title: U4U Supporter
item.dc:creator: dbalin30
item.content:encoded:
U4U Supporter

Criteria for being a U4U Supporter:

  • Lawful Status in US
    • US Citizen
    • Green Card Holder
    • Asylee
    • TPS Holder
    • Other people on U4U or HP
  • Passed Security and Background Checks
  • Has sufficient financial resources to support refugee

Finding a Supporter:

ðŸ’Œ Ukrainians applying for the Uniting for Ukraine Program often find support through relatives or close friends residing in the United States who are willing to act as sponsors. It is recommended to reach out to distant family, friends, family friends, or other contacts within the United States who may be willing to support your application. Personal connections often provide the most reliable and trustworthy support.

Canâ€™t find a Supporterâ€¦

In cases where you do not have anyone in the U.S. who can act as a supporter, there are several resources and platforms available to help you find a suitable supporter. Consider exploring websites, social media groups, and organizations dedicated to aiding Ukrainian refugees in the U.S. Some recommended resources include:

  • From https://refugees.novaukraine.org/uniting-for-ukraine/ :
    • Welcome.Us
    • UkraineNow
    • North America for Ukraine
    • USA/Canada: Host, Sponsor, Help
    • Helping Ukrainian Refugees in the USA
    • North America for Ukraine
    • USA Sponsor Uniting for Ukraine
    • Help Ukrainian Refugees
    • Sponsor in the USA (Uniting for Ukraine)
    • Uniting for Ukraine
    • Uniting for Ukraine- US Sponsorship
    • Accommodation, Help and Shelter for Ukraine
    • Uniting for Ukraine (U4U) BENEFICIARY FORM (Supporters in Connecticut only)
    • Ukraine Relief Program (Supporters and help with resettlement in Alaska)

item.title: Application Process
item.dc:creator: dbalin30
item.content:encoded:
Application Process

Overview of the U4U Application Process:

The U4U application process involves several important steps to ensure that individuals and their families can apply for humanitarian parole through the Uniting for Ukraine program. By carefully following these steps, applicants can increase their chances of a successful application outcome.

Step 1: Gather Required Documents:

Before starting the application process, it is crucial to gather the necessary documents. The exact document requirements may vary, but generally, you will need the following:

  1. Valid Ukrainian Passport: Ensure that you have a valid Ukrainian passport for each applicant, including children. If children are included, they can be listed on their parent's passport.
  2. Proof of Displacement: Provide documentation demonstrating that you have resided in Ukraine prior to the conflict and have been displaced as a result. This may include residency records, utility bills, lease agreements, or any other relevant documents.
  3. Form I-134A: This form should be completed by your U.S.-based supporter, pledging financial support and commitment throughout your stay in the United States.
  4. Biographic Information: Prepare biographic information for each applicant, including full name, address, date of birth, and passport details.

Step 2: Complete Form I-134A:

Form I-134A, Declaration of Financial Support, is a critical document that needs to be filled out accurately and completely. This form is typically completed by your U.S.-based supporter, who will provide information about their financial capacity to support you during your stay in the United States. The form should include your biographic details, passport information, income, assets, and any other relevant information.

Step 3: Supporter's Application Submission:

Once the Form I-134A is completed by your supporter, they will submit the application on your behalf. The supporter's application will be reviewed and vetted by the immigration service to ensure they meet the requirements and can provide the necessary support.

Step 4: USCIS Review and Decision:

The U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) will review the supporter's application, including Form I-134A and supporting documentation. USCIS will evaluate the financial sufficiency of the supporter and conduct biographic security checks. It may take up to three months for USCIS to issue a decision on the application.

  • CONFIRM Notice: If the supporter's application is approved, USCIS will send a CONFIRM Notice to you, the beneficiary. This notice confirms that the supporter's application has been successful, and you can proceed with the next steps of the application process.
  • NON CONFIRM Notice: In the event that the supporter's application is found insufficient, USCIS will issue a NON CONFIRM Notice, indicating that the application did not meet the necessary requirements. In such cases, further action may be required, including the possibility of finding an alternative supporter.

Step 5: Create an Online Account:

Upon receiving the CONFIRM Notice from USCIS, you will be instructed to create an online account on the USCIS website. This account will serve as a platform for you to manage your application and access important information throughout the process.

Step 6: Complete Biographic Information and Attestations:

Using your USCIS online account, you will need to provide accurate biographic information for each family member included in your application. Additionally, you will be required to complete attestations regarding vaccine requirements, including measles, polio, and the first dose of a COVID-19 vaccine. Proof of vaccination is not necessary at this stage, and any outstanding vaccinations can be completed after your arrival in the United States.

Step 7: Travel Authorization Decision:

After submitting the necessary information and completing the required attestations, USCIS will review your application. The travel authorization decision for each member of your travel group will be posted in the Notices section of your USCIS case. It may take several weeks for USCIS to post the decisions, with non-Ukrainian family members typically experiencing longer wait times.

Step 8: Print Travel Authorizations:

Once all travel authorizations have been granted, it is important to print them out. These authorizations will be required for boarding your flight and when passing through U.S. passport control upon arrival.

item.title: Other Types of Visas
item.dc:creator: dbalin30
item.content:encoded:
Other Types of Visas

Visitor

  • The B-1/B-2 Visitor Visa is a temporary visa.
    • It allows individuals to travel to the United States for business or pleasure.
    • The B-1 visa is for those who wish to engage in business activities.
    • The B-2 visa is for those who wish to visit the United States for tourism, medical treatment, or to visit family or friends.
    • Individuals who enter the United States on a B-1/B-2 visa are not allowed to engage in any employment or receive any payment while in the United States.
    • The duration of stay allowed on a B-1/B-2 visa is typically six months, but it can be extended in certain circumstances.

Student

  • F-1 Student Visa: This visa is for students who want to study at an accredited U.S. college or university. To qualify for an F-1 visa, you must be accepted to a U.S. school and have enough financial resources to support yourself during your studies.
  • M-1 Student Visa: This visa is for students who want to study at a vocational or non-academic institution in the United States. To qualify for an M-1 visa, you must be accepted to a U.S. school and have enough financial resources to support yourself during your studies.

Workers

  • H-1B Visa: This visa is for temporary workers in specialty occupations that require a bachelor's degree or the equivalent. To qualify for an H-1B visa, you must have a job offer from a U.S. employer and the employer must file a petition on your behalf with the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS).
  • L-1 Visa: This visa is for intracompany transferees who are coming to the United States to work for a branch or subsidiary of their foreign employer. To qualify for an L-1 visa, you must have been working for the foreign employer for at least one year in the past three years.

Other

  • J-1 Visa: This visa is for exchange visitors who are coming to the United States to participate in an educational, cultural, or training program. To qualify for a J-1 visa, you must be sponsored by a U.S. exchange program sponsor.
  • K-1 fiancÃ©(e) visa (K1)
  • K-2 child of K-1 visa holder (K2)

Resources:

  • **Uniting for Ukraine: https://www.uscis.gov/ukraine**  - This is a new program created by the U.S. government to allow Ukrainian citizens and their immediate family members to come to the United States temporarily for two years. To be eligible, you must have a supporter in the United States who agrees to provide you with financial support for the duration of your stay.
  • **U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS): https://www.uscis.gov/** - USCIS is the government agency that handles immigration matters in the United States. You can find more information about visas and other immigration options for Ukrainian refugees on their website.
  • **Department of State: https://travel.state.gov/** - The Department of State is responsible for issuing visas to people who want to travel to the United States. You can find more information about Ukrainian visas on their website.
  • **International Rescue Committee (IRC): https://www.rescue.org/**  - The IRC is a non-profit organization that provides humanitarian aid to refugees and other displaced people around the world. They have a dedicated team working on helping Ukrainian refugees, and they can provide you with information and resources about visas and other immigration options.
  • **Church World Service (CWS): https://www.cwsglobal.org/**  - CWS is another non-profit organization that provides humanitarian aid to refugees. They have a resettlement program for Ukrainian refugees, and they can help you with the visa process and finding a place to live in the United States.
